>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Only multitool I need. Leatherman wave.
Got it as a gift ages ago and really love it as a good alrounder. You have quick access to the cutting tools and it has stuff you can at least get some use out of, rather than 50 features I do neither want nor need. It's built like a tank and has withstood some insane abuse by me, including leaving it outside for over a year in a bowl that collected rain and snow. All I got was this matte patina, it still works perfectly.
It's very expensive, but you notice the quality your money gets you at least and for me due to the memories I made with it and it being a gift by my parents I have become emotionally attached to it at this point.
>tell me why you think it's the perfect one for you
Has all the features I regularly use, but not many more. Sturdy, doesn't get damaged easily, good form factor, gets the job done for basically any task, be it cutting wire, holding things, pulling thorns out of my skin, cracking nuts, cutting things, or anything related. Pair it with a extra knife for fishing that is easy to clean and you got 80% of usecases covered and can probably improvise something with it for the other 20%.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
In the coming weeks, I plan to hike and camp along one of the trails in my local state park. Since the trail is only 25 miles, I will only be staying for 2 nights. I currently only have the following items:
>55L bag with camel pack
>Sleeping bag
>Tent
>Headlamp
>Hip flask
>Hatchet
>space blanket

What else should I bring or account for?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503915
Assuming it might rain but not snow (you shouldn't go out in freezing temps at all with your level of experience), you'll want:

>pack cover of some sort (can be a poncho) and method to secure it
>ground sheet (can also be a poncho)
>extra layers if it's at all cool/cold where you are
>weather protection (pack jacket, poncho again, rain fly, etc.)
>extra socks and underwear, also one more shirt and pair of pants than you think you'll need (this is in addition to layers)
>entrenching tool and TP
>water filter AND iodine, although springs are virtually always pure; filtering spring water is a Big Filter psyop
>first aid kit, preferably one you assemble yourself
>general survival tools: a good knoife, Leatherman perhaps, signal mirror, several fire-starting methods, the space blanket you already have, flare gun, rape whistle, cordage (paracord, twine, wire, etc.), aluminum foil, satellite S&R beacon, etc.
>a topo map and base plate compass if you know how to use those, otherwise you'll have your smartphone I suppose (bring a power bank)
>more food than you think you need (you have room) and as much water as you can reasonably carry
>hiking stove of some kind
>compression dry bag for critical items inside your pack
>sleeping pad and/or self-inflating mattress
>bring a second headlamp (or also a small Maglite or w/e) and a method to recharge both

There's more, but I'm done taking a shit here at work. Have fun, and I stress thay if you're new to this and go out in freezing temps, you'll probably die.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503591
The chassies are for moving air. The frame, roll cage, and everything else structural are some sort of metal alloy. Overspifying and mostly accurate: the crystal content of a material determines its strength and plasticity--the more % crystal usually the stronger a material is but it also is more brittle. An extreme comparison would be a pure iron rod and a pure diamond rod--the diamond will shatter under strain while the iron rod will bend...although it will take much more strain to shatter the diamond than bend the iron. In carbon fiber the crystal content is the graphite, which is hexagonally bonded carbon layered in a polymer. The other important factor is cyclic fatigue stresses. Over time carbon fiber will develop mocrocracking because it cracks instead of bends where metal this is much less prevent. The end result is carbon fiber can fail completely under a strain (especially in cold where the crystals cool and become more brittle) where metals will bend and distort but not fail.
Thanks for listening to my TED talk.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2502659
Australia is somewhat of an exception, considering that it has 2.2 million square miles of outback.

No one (even folks currently living a subsistence/survivalist lifestyle) has the time or resources to literally just walk everywhere. The Aborigines (and, in the Americas, Mesoamericans, as well as Native Americans before Europeans introduced horses to the continent) did walk everywhere, and of course so did all pre-agricultural tribes, but their entire civilization (if any) and way of life supported this.

Our upbringing and civilization do not support walking everywhere. We need our horses (which the modern world also is no longer set up to fully support), wagons, or cars.

But some people take it way too far, driving absolutely everywhere they possibly can and getting out only when 100% necessary, maybe even toting ATVs along to ensure as close to 0 walking as possible. Lazy and flabby and out of shape is what it leads to, as well as shitting up wild areas with more vehicles and the infrastructure to support them (built by authorities under pressure from lardasses).

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Beginner Gear General - Poor Fag Edition
threads.com:
I wanted to make a thread for General new gear and where to get it. Also for Larpers and Woodsman alike to avoid the pit falls I fell into when choosing gear for the first time over 2 years ago. i'll try to aim for a good gear loadout under 200$. Also any criticisms or better options should be talked about here.

Ill first go by stating the things no anon should ever cheap out on.
>boots
you should aim for boots over 200$ price range eventually, but if you are just getting started buy military surplus boots. But If you can avoid do not buy the recent desert tan army boots that run 20$. They have very thick soles and no ankle support , its a good way to give yourself a sprang ankle, they are also not very breathable or water proof. But I used them for a year so they are workable but do have a week or 2 brake in period.

Next is backpacks I see many on here choose a military surplus backpack, My experience with a US military molle 2 rucksack is that its usable at best but too heavy. Military sacrifices price and quality material for an indestructible pack that an idiot can't destroy. You are better off with a used frame backpack or internal backpack.

I have found that most milltary backpacks are around 65-120$ a used backpacking bag is around 20$ on shopgoodwill.com. I hear you say that you don't want to stand out in the woods , I would say their are plenty of waterproof rain flys for your bag that come in non-IRreflective camo for 45$ or a Chinese rain fly for 10$ on amazon, which are better than what ever camo you were thinking about buying any how. A good capacity is 65 liters, this is considered 3 day bag but if your smart you can fit rations for a full week in it. 55 liters is fine but the limit for fitting a sleeping bag and not limiting the gear you might want to take. Finally you need to have a waist support for your backpack as well as a frame , this should go without saying a duffel bag is a pain to hull around 5 miles.

go watch greg judy regenerative rancher
everyone here is a larping faggot
nice digits
generally for sheep/goat you will have 5 or less per acre. every faggot wants goats until they realize how much of a nightmare they are to keep from running away. sheep's issue is that they are retarded and open game for sheep season 24/7/365 to coyotes. you need a dogs for that that are trained to follow sheep and bark at anything else. pyreness is one, but have to find a good place to buy sheep/dogs born into this.
st croix is a good sheep for parasite resistance if you want a hair sheep (meat sheep). if you feed sheep grain you will have to deal with more issues of hoof trimming and parasites. sheep are good for silviculture or mix of pasture/tree since they can use the tree for cover instead of a barn that is a beacon of parasites
if you can you want a rotation of field to avoid parasites. use electric fence and move sheep to a new acre of half acre every day or two depending on how much rainfall you get.
you don't want sheep to eat the ground bare where the shit is.
goats are generally browsers and will look for things to eat. they can be good for eating at shrubs and bushes and other crap. they will graze if their zone is barren, but this is the source of their curiosity.
sheep are more grazers like cattle.
also, some animals don't share the same parasites so you can, for example, alternate your rotation where cattle and sheep share a field because sheep shit won't give the same parasites to cattle.
goats can also be milked, but you have to do it regularly like twice a day. if you want it easy and part time, go with sheep.

>>2503555
Why do you want to run stock? Meat? Dairy? Wool? You need to consider these things.

Because you are a noob at this I would highly suggest running sheep first as goats can be hard to run if you are not experienced. I would suggest running a meat breed (this is a breed of sheep that is bred for meat). What you want to do is go on something like Marketplace, Gumtree, or a livestock selling site and buy weaned lambs, make sure not to buy an uncastrated male. his primary role is to breed, weaning is a process where the lambs are drenched, immunized, castrated, de tailed and dehorned, basically they become ready to farm. Once you do that buy some containers for water and set up some (one or two) simple shelters (star picquets and corrugated iron will do it). You can rather let them graze your land, strip graze (this is done with a mobile electric fence. You set up the sheep in a strip of your land, fencing them in with the electric fence, basically making them eat a section of grass while the rest of the sections regrow) or you can feed them pellets. You will also need to drench your sheep too, drench is medicine that is inserted orally with a drench gun (I'll attach a pic) this will need to be done once every month or so. I'm going to guess you are from Texas, you will want to get a sheep dog to look after the sheep, these dogs are usually expensive but worth it, DO NOT TRAIN THE DOG YOURSELF, where I'm from we usually use blue heelers or kelpies, also important to mention that these dogs should never treat these animals like pets, they are working dogs. Also buying a 223 and popping some pests would help too, where I'm from there's a nationwide gun club that helps farmers by sending out hunters to remove pests, maybe the NRA does something like this??? Sheep are also VERY retarded, use you voice, hands and body language to herd them, you can also buy an ag bike or a quad to herd but you really shouldn't need it. AMA if you have any questions.

last_replies.com:
>>2503124
the lakes I go to in the deep south have tards with bass boats that do 70mph the second they get far enough away from the dock. you just have to brace for the wakes and it's fine. most kayakers here stay out in the middle when they're covering distance, which sounds like the opposite of what you'd want to do, but it makes sense considering the wakes are rougher if you're alone the bank and a boat sends one out towards you. either way, a stable kayak will be fine. you just have to choose one that also paddles well, a lot of stable "fishing kayaks" paddle like shit, although you wouldn't notice until you've tried other kayaks. I don't know how windy it gets up there, but wind should also play a huge role in your kayak selection, fighting wind can be rough. at the end of the day, you can make due with anything and it's better to be out there in the first place than not, but chop and wakes aren't as dangerous as you would think at face value unless you're in a very unstable kayak or just don't pay attention and brace for them.

there are two methods for making wool machine washable. three if you count felting/fulling. four if you count sheep breeds whose wool doesn't readily felt. merino is about as far from one of those breeds as can be. washable merino wool has either gone through the chemical process you're referencing which burns away the scales or it's been coated in the plastic bullshit which eventually gets worn off with enough washings and stops being "washable". both methods are referred to as superwash. anon is either being a disingenuous shitter or knows fuckall about fiber. good superwash has gone through the chemical burn bath and has been spun/milled to best mitigate its propensity to felt together. only real effects on the end material are all structural. superwash stretches out of shape easier, particularly when wet, and has a tendency to "grow" with wearing. performance wise the functional properties remain the same.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
if you want sustainable, you want to go back to the basics: wool, cotton, linen/hemp.
One problem with a lot of the clothing today is we have a lot more knits than wovens. Look at what people are wearing outside all day ranching. Usually cotton weave shirts. They regulate heat better than a t shirt and blocks the sun better for being a long sleeve.
What it also does is serve as a thin layer that doesn't retain water as well as a t shirt would.
Since woven's are not next to skin and don't facilitate with modern fashion is that they drape much farther away from the body. For outerwear, this means water rolls off the sides a lot easier before it contaminate your skin and any wind dries it out much faster than it would next to skin. Probably why people centuries ago wore cloaks, luhkka's, great coats, over coats and other loose fits. I wondered why sailors wore slops, until I wore some loose Dickies 874's fishing all day where it rained 90% of the day. While my pants would get wet:
a) my skin infrequently touched the wet spots
b) during any dry moment, the wind would dry them out in a fairly short area.
They functioned in a way different than water proofness and instead were dry fast and keep the wet spots off of you.

If you need water off you, there is always the waxed cotton like the Australian slicker coat and those English waxed coats. You basically never wash those materials.
>not saying go 100% back to natural garments
it has been discussed to death though that using these waterproof agents is making an uncomfortable bargain for something that:
a) is expensive, and not always sewn in well since a lot of goretex needs fixing in a year.
b) creates a climate barrier slowing down sweats ability to vent
c) then makes for an uncomfortable experience.

threads.com: What’s your favorite style of camping, on a scale of car camping to multi-day hikes? I think there’s kind of a ratio of how much comfort to adventure you prefer. My sweet spot for enjoyable camping is hiking in, but to a place only a couple miles from the car. I particularly like places where it’s a steep climb over a somewhat short distance, so you get a comfy campsite with a nice view. That way it’s not boring like just car camping but the distance is also short enough that you can have a heavy pack with “unnecessary” comforts like beer or a thick air mattress. What do you think?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503003
It really depends on the location. If it's scenic af I definitely like to backpack for a few days, maybe 40-50km, but not too much more. If the trail is boring or is mostly just a random road, I don't wanna hike much unless the camping spot is amazing. Therefore I mostly try to hike in and explore forests without any trails, makes the process really interesting.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Backpacking for sure. Usually around 4-5 hours of hiking a day, 1-2 nights is what I like to aim for. People on the trail are more friendly than people at campgrounds, cool views, good exercise. A warm meal after a tough hike is also one of the best feelings. You can still be comfy, I carry a flask and a folding chair as my comfort items so I can have a little sippy by the fire.

Still love car camping for the fires and camp food, but these days campsites can be booked weeks/months in advance, have to use their overpriced firewood, have to register my car with the ranger, sites are cramped together. Just so many hoops to jump through instead of just parking my car at a trailhead and going.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I hate camping, I'd much rather sleep in a comfy bed, otherwise I sleep like dogshit. Glamping is a little better. Hotels are nicer. My preference is to explore during the day then get back to "base camp", whether that's a car camp, a hotel, my house, etc. A van would be perfect for that but I can't afford it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503003
Ideally 4 whole days, hiking around 50 miles, and never camping in the same spot. The lower mileage allows me to take more breaks, enjoy the scenery, and occasionally explore.

Most trips are only one or two nights. With driving a two night trip is less than three whole days. It’s not ideal but it’s still fun. I enjoy hiking, but if I have to hike more than 15 miles in a day I feel like I’m missing out.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503596
This sounds rad. I am looking at a something this this in fair weather next year to involve friends who don't have the time or inclination to do multi day hikes.

Preferred is multi day back packing. It's hard to get more than a long weekend in with work but that's why I like it. I don't need to be dead at the end of a hike but it's nice when I'm tired enough to go right to sleep. I like to make the last day a little shorter so that there's time to change or at least briefly relax off trail before returning home. A late lunch or dinner and a beer is a good way to cap off a trip before returning to the daily grind. I don't mind occasionally car camping sometimes but unless chosen well the sites are often boring or in state parks down right unconformable. It does make a nice alternative to a hotel on a roadtrip though, just got to plot your travel to go by some nat forest or blm land.

Budget for a ski season:
Boots: = $500/5 seasons = $100
Skis is same (buy used), so another $100
Poles = $50/5 = $10
Jacket, $200/5 = $40
Pants, $200/5 = $40
socks, helmet, other personal items: $300/5 = $60

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503525
>Is there any danger in being so close to the antennas?
The 2way/LMR stuff isn't too bad. 100 watts or so with a couple dB antenna gain on it. Unless you're really close to it or working on the specific antenna when it's still lit up, there's not much of an exposure hazard. Those duty-cycle too, they're only on when someone's using the talk path, so overall exposure is reduced because of the time factor.
Dishes or directional antennas focus that energy in one direction; while they usually have less power into them, all that power is directed one way. Don't stand or work in front of those.
Broadcast transmitters are the scary ones. Lots of power, 100% duty cycle, and they're usually in bands that the body absorbs easily.
The tower in >picrel is AM broadcast, the tower structure is the antenna and it's electrically hot. Knocked power down while we were on it, less for exposure and more to minimize the risk of RF burns in case of accidental contact with the grounded cables I was installing. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b9UO9tn4MpI
On top of that tower was a 10-element FM broadcast array with about 50kW out of it.
When I climbed up to set an anchor the day before the install, knowing the two of us were only going to be up there for a short time, we didn't mess with the FM power levels. My alarm got real alarmy up there because of that exposure. The next day during the install, I coordinated with station engineer to ramp down power on that transmitter to acceptable levels while I was working ~15ft below that array.

Part of my pre-climb safety assessment includes RF exposure considerations.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
feel like first aid kit is pretty specific to your activity and risk tolerance. don't buy a kit and assume it will cover everything you need, usually there is a ton of stuff in there that has no practical value and too little of things like moleskin which might actually make your trip enjoyable. here's my thoughts generally:

annoying injuries - stuff like cuts, blisters, headache... are pretty common and not trip ending. most of this is pretty easy to treat too so it makes sense to bring with some little bandaids or meds to make the trip less miserable if they occur.

trip ending - these are less common and not life threatening but serious enough that you would be unable to continue with your activity. mostly this is the falling over category where you end with broken bones or larger cuts. most of this isn't immediately life threatening but requires more care than you can do in the field. your goal here is to provide a way to self rescue back to somewhere you can get better care, splints and gauze/quickclot are the big items here and depending on how big your risk for this is can either be dedicated equipment in your kit or improvised from your other gear.

emergency - this is stuff you are actually going to die from and usually there isn't a ton you can do for yourself in this case. if you are in a group it makes sense to bring some trauma kit to help stabilize but solo your best bet is to seriously consider the risk and either adjust or avoid the activities that might cause these kind of injuries if the risk is unacceptable. this is also the category you would start carrying some kind of PLB for as the best you can hope for is to stabilize the situation and then hope rescue comes before death does.

medicine - a few pain meds, a few asprin (heart attack), something for alergic reactions, and any prescription is really all you need. this is ignoring any specialty stuff like for high altitude sicknesses or opioids for self rescue.

threads.com:
I want to go walking in Norway for a month or two between May and August next year, ideally somewhere in the far north around Tromso og Finnmark.
I don't want to stick to paths but I don't want to be wading through should height bogs, not sure if those are a problem outside of the UK.
My experience in Scandinavia is limited to Lillehammer and Svalbard in summer and general experience will just be walking around the UK.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
May is too early. Mid to end of June has a lot of mosquitos right after the snowmelt. July and August will be best. If you like autumn and can handle the weather and a bit of snow September is very nice as well.

No need to stick to trails above the treeline but you will get bogs everywhere even on marked trails. How deep they are depends on how much it has been raining.

The most scenic route is the Nordkalottleden. You can hike the northern section in two to three weeks or otherwise build your trail around it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: and also if this is your first/primary backpack, i agree with you op 40-45 liters is the right size for most people for this. the one specific thing to look for is a pack that cinches down to smaller sizes well and carries well when it does. that way you can use this same backpack for your day-hikes and also your shorter backpacking trips, instead of needing two separate packs. not all backpacks 'scale down' well. picrel is an example of a good design.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: the other thing to look for when buying is the torso length of the pack. have a friend measure your torso for you. when anon and i say basically any pack will work for you, its with the caveat: has to fit well. if you're looking at either cheap or lightweight packs they're often not very adjustable so make sure to get it right. watch a few videos on youtube about how to fit a pack & bring a simulated load to fill it up with if you have the luxury of buying your backpack in person at a store.

Resort skiing is a good solo activity. Almost more fun than with friends since you can get in way more runs, set your own pace, and never have to wait for your group at the bottom of the liftline. I wouldn't recommend backcountry skiing solo, too high risk. A lot more can go wrong and can be unrecoverable alone.
XC mountain biking and gravel biking solo is fantastic. Downhill I find more fun in groups, but when trying to make distance on trails, solo is the way to go.
Snowshoeing in the winter is another good solo one, not really a sport like the other two but still very peaceful.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Anyone live in Utah that could discuss usual weather conditions for the state? What part has more cold and what has more heat? Where’s the best place to go camping, hiking? Any good urban areas? Is Salt Lake City even worth visiting?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I lived in Las Vegas for a few decades and can speak about the southern half of Utah. The temperature in St. George is only a few degrees cooler than Vegas so highs of roughly 100 F in summer and lows of 30-35 F in winter. They have Bryce Canyon and Zion, both national parks and both worth visiting but crowded. There is also Lake Powell and the North Rim of the Grand Canyon although I've never been to either one.

By far my favorite place was the Dixie National Forest just east of Cedar City. While most of Southern Utah is semi-arid, most of the DNF is on a plain at roughly 10,000 feet and consequently more alpine. There are two larger lakes there, Panguitch and Navajo, both with a good deal of trout. Not much in the way of backpacking, the Dixie National Forest is ideal for camping because you can pull off anywhere and make your campsite.

I had a filson but didnt like it for out that much. I much prefer the anorak designs.
